body: In a poverty-stricken South Bronx neighborhood, a pastor gathered a group of children around a Nativity scene and pointed out the humble conditions of Jesus' birth. ''Don't be ashamed of being poor,'' the pastor, the Rev. John Grange, told them. ''Jesus was born in a manger, and He became King of Kings.'' Last night, as Christmas approached,
title: CHRISTMAS EVE SERVICES: A MESSAGE FOR OUR TIME

body: IN New York, there is a Christmas less obvious than the window displays along Fifth Avenue, the Christmas tree in Rockefeller Center and the tree under the arch in Washington Square. But, New York's hidden Christmas, unlike that in many cities, is not only the sum total of many small, personal expressions - like the tinsel wrapped around a trash
title: CITY SIGHTS: HOLIDAY SURPRISES WORTH LOOKING FOR

body: Positive Results When Paul Snyder, the director of scouting and minor-league operations for the Atlanta Braves, was able to lose 52 pounds after just one consultation with a Brooklyn doctor who specializes in positive-thinking techniques, he considered the doctor ''a godsend.'' body: In much the same way that stereo headphones once began appearing on the ears of subway riders, replacing the screech of skidding steel wheels with Beethoven or the Rolling Stones, earplugs are now showing up in the ears of New Yorkers. body: A young woman came out of the subway at 137th Street and Broadway and walked quickly by a dozen men with slurry eyes lounging on broken benches and sipping from bottles wrapped in brown paper bags. body: Not since the late 1950's, when Sputnik was launched, has American education come in for as much scrutiny as it is getting today - and educators in New York City are loving it. title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: HOPES OF CHANGE IN CITY SCHOOLS

body: A Brooklyn man was killed and four other men were wounded yesterday in what the police described as a gangland-style shooting in front of a coffee shop in the Bensonhurst section at 2:15 A.M. title: THE CITY; Brooklyn Man Is Slain on Street

body: Friday ITALIAN FOLK MUSIC REVIVED Although Italian folk music was a vital part of daily life among early Italian immigrants, it isn't well known to later Italian-American generations, according to the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, which has set out to help rectify the situation. title: WEEKENDER GUIDE

body: New York City's Board of Elections last week completed its unofficial count of the May 3 community school board elections. body: Three black men on their way home from their hospital jobs in Brooklyn were assaulted early yesterday by a group of whites in what the police called a racially motivated attack. title: GROUP OF WHITES ASSAULTS 3 BLACK MEN IN BROOKLYN

body: A sniper fired four shots at two police officers writing parking summonses in front of 265 Cherry Street on the Lower East Side at about 5:40 A.M. yesterday. title: THE CITY; The Police Blotter

body: Politicians have become more involved this year in New York City's district school board campaigns than in any of the previous five elections since 1970, according to politicians and educators. title: ELECTING BOARDS FOR CITY SCHOOLS HAS POLITICAL AIR

body: They are unlikely spots for excellence - two junior high schools situated on blocks surrounded by burned-out tenements and abandoned lots. body: The Real Toy Buyers T he snow began in Madison Square yesterday as a hundred children broke their huddle and marched - following a promotion director as if a Pied Piper - to ''welcome'' buyers to the annual 10-day market at the Toy Fair Building at 200 Fifth Avenue. title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: A guard arrested at a hotel in San Juan, P.R., and charged with stealing $11 million from a Bronx security concern, has waived extradition and will return to New York this weekend, officials said today. title: THE CITY; Sentry Co. Guard Agrees to Return

body: The guard who was on duty on the night of an $11 million theft at a Bronx armored-car company and a friend of his were charged yesterday with stealing the money and attempting to camouflage the crime as an armed robbery. In announcing the arrests, Federal and New York law-enforcement authorities said none of the money had been recovered. The
title: ARMORED-CAR GUARD AND FRIEND ARRESTED IN $11 MILLION THEFT

body: More than a third of the students in New York City high schools are chronically absent and miss so much class time that it is nearly impossible to teach them, according to the Board of Education. An additional 13 percent of the students are absent often enough to require extraordinary efforts by teachers to keep them up to grade level. Chronically
title: THIRD OF CITY HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS ATTEND CLASS TOO SELDOM TO LEARN

body: Following are the scores, released by the New York City Board of Education, on the reading tests given in city's public elementary schools and junior high schools in April 1982. The center column shows the proportion of pupils in each school reading at or above grade level; the right-hand column gives each school's overall city-wide ranking.
title: Scores on Reading Tests Given in Public Schools

body: A 24-year-old man was arrested on a Brooklyn street near his home yesterday morning and charged with being one of two men who had held up a coin and stamp shop and had stolen goods worth $125,000, the police said. The police were also checking a report the men had kidnapped a customer who carried a badge and gun. The holdup took place Wednesday
title: THE CITY; Suspect Arrested In Stamp Robbery
